segments.text: Well, usually the terrorism is aimed at the company first.
The larger the company, the greater visibility it's going to get as far as the worldwide opinion is concerned, and that's usually what the terrorists are looking for.
A subsidiary advantage that they're looking for, of course, is the effect of whatever attack they're making on the company, on the local political situation, but
Very rarely is a terrorism directed at an individual unless he's of such a level or has been so influential in local politics, particularly, that they want him out of the way.
And normally, an executive of a multinational company does not achieve that level of local prominence.
So that the attacks are not directed against people personally, generally.
They're just intended to get the maximum effect of world opinion.
I heard a plant of yours was burnt down.
What was that?
Well, that was June 19th, 1969.

Governor Rockefeller was planning a trip through Latin America, and the day before he was scheduled to retire, the terrorists at 1 o'clock in the morning, this was the Tupomaro terrorists in Uruguay, burned the administration building and attempted to burn our entire plant in Uruguay.
A very small operation.
We only had 350 employees, but it was one of the biggest in the country at the time.
And for world effect, it was very effective on their part.
It was the first time that an American installation had been subjected to this kind of international terrorism.
And they certainly got quite a bit of press coverage as a result of it.
Funny part about it is that the effect on the local people in Uruguay was exactly contrary to what the terrorists had expected.
There was a tremendous howl of outrage at every level, from government to employees.
As a matter of fact, the employees
were very upset when we tried to pay overtime for their work in rebuilding the facilities.
They wanted to donate their time.
It was a very, very flattering and comforting thing to see that kind of reaction of the Uruguayans themselves to an attack that was calculated to drive them exactly in the other direction.
It's nice to see.
It sure is.
Well, thank you very much.
Thank you, Ms. Katz.
Thank you.
you
Thank you.
Thank you.
Thank you.
Amen.
Thank you.
Thank you.
